{{Globalize/US|date=October 2016}} [[File:Police checkpoint, Queens Drive, Swindon (2) - geograph.org.uk - 572430.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Police officers stop a motorist and check the motorist's documents at a [[random checkpoint]].]] [[File:TTC teacher2.JPG|thumb|right|200px|An elementary school teacher instructing her students.]] [[File:Wikiedit training at the School of Social Work, Roshni Nilaya, Mangalore, by Ms Harriot.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A social worker in India teaches her clients how to use a laptop. As an exercise, she is showing them how to edit the [[Wikipedia]] online encyclopedia.]] {{Politics sidebar|Admin}} '''Street-level bureaucracy''' is the subset of a [[Public administration|public agency or government institution]] where the [[civil servant]]s work who have direct contact with members of the general public. Street-level civil servants carry out and/or enforce the actions required by a government's laws and [[public policy|public policies]], in areas ranging from safety and security to education and [[social service]]s. A few examples include [[police officer]]s, [[border guard]]s, [[social worker]]s and public school [[teacher]]s. These civil servants have direct contact with members of the general public, in contrast with civil servants who do [[policy analysis]] or [[economic]] analysis, who do not meet the public. Street-level bureaucrats act as liaisons between government policy-makers and citizens and these civil servants implement policy decisions made by senior officials in the public service and/or by elected officials.
Street-level bureaucrats interact and communicate with the general public, either in person (as with a police officer doing a [[random checkpoint]] to check for [[drunk driving]] or a civil servant in a department of transportation who helps people to register a newly purchased car and provide them with [[licence plate]]s); over the phone (as with a government [[call center]], where civil servants answer phone calls from people who are applying for or receiving [[unemployment insurance]]); or, in jurisdictions which have implemented [[electronic government]] technologies, via the [[Internet]] (e.g., a person finding out about the government's [[taxation law]]s by going onto the taxation department's official [[website]] and asking questions to a civil servant via [[email]]).
Street-level bureaucrats often have some degree of [[discretion]] on how they enforce the rules, laws and policies which they are assigned to uphold. For example, a police officer who catches a speeding motorist typically can decide whether to give the driver a warning or apply a penalty such as a fine or criminal charge; a [[border guard]] who finds undeclared rum in a border-crossing motorist's car trunk can either give the person a warning, confiscate and destroy the [[contraband]] item, or levy a fine or other penalty; a government social worker who meets with an unemployed person can decide whether or not to provide [[social assistance]] or unemployment insurance benefits; and a high school [[Principal (education)|principal]] who finds that a student is [[truancy|skipping school]] can decide whether or not to suspend the person, taking into account the student's unique circumstances and situation. Even though front-line bureaucrats have this degree of discretion, they typically must operate within the [[rule of law]], the system of government [[regulation]]s, [[law]]s and [[administrative law|administrative procedural rules]]. These regulations, laws and rules help to ensure that the street-level bureaucracy operates fairly and ethically, and that each citizen is treated fairly.
== History == The concept of street-level bureaucracy was first coined by [[Michael Lipsky]] in 1969(<ref name="Lipsky, Michael 1969">Lipsky, Michael (1969). Toward a Theory of Street-Level Bureaucracy (IRP Discussion Papers No. 48-69) (p. 45). Madison, WI: Institute for Research on Poverty (IRP), University of Wisconsin. Retrieved from http://www.irp.wisc.edu/publications/dps/pdfs/dp4869.pdf</ref>), who argued that "policy implementation in the end comes down to the people [(the street-level bureaucrats)] who actually implement it". However, the process of street-level bureaucracy has been around for a much longer period. A "government will be better accepted if its administrators [e.g., bureaucrats] reflect the origins [and needs] of its people", <ref>Cooke, Scott A.; Klay, William Earle. "George Washington's Precedents: The Institutional Legacy of the American Republic's Founding Public Administrator". ''Administration & Society'' 2015: 75-91. Online.</ref> an ideal which embodies the goals of an effective street-level bureaucracy in America. Some of the first street-level bureaucrats in the US were [[post office]] officials and administrators. The presidency of [[Woodrow Wilson]] helped to spur a large growth in public administration and government policy-making, which in turn led to larger-sized and better-funded street-level bureaucracies. However it was not until the 1950s with the [[baby boom]] that street level bureaucracy became as strong as a presence in society as it is in the 2000s.
Lipsky describes street level bureaucrats as the "human face" of policy, since these individuals interact directly with citizens.<ref name="Lipsky, Michael 1980">Lipsky, Michael. Street-level Bureaucracy: Dilemmas of the Individual in Public Services. New York, NY: Russell Sage Foundation, 1980. Print.</ref> The history of street-level bureaucracy follows the history of policy development and the scope of government in America, with areas with larger populations and more government policies employing more public servants (e.g., Chicago which employs 26,680 teachers).(<ref name="Lipsky, Michael 1980"/>) Due to street-level bureaucrats' close interactions with citizens, day-to-day application of discretion in their assessment of people's cases and issues, and their role as policy interpreters, Lipsky claims that "in a sense the street-level bureaucrats implicitly mediate aspects of the [[Constitution|constitutional]] relationship of citizens to the state. In short, they hold the keys to a dimension of [[citizenship]]."(<ref>Lipksy, Michael. Street-level Bureaucracy. N.p.: n.p., 1980. Print.</ref>) The interpretation of the duties, scope, and responsibilities of street-level bureaucrats are still debated in the 2000s, with ongoing discussion on the roles of discretion, accountability, lack of resources, and technology and concerns raised about the risks of corruption.
== Demand and need == Where there is population growth, there is usually growth in demand for these occupations, because there are more citizens who need public services. The demand for these occupations will vary by region but generally, the job outlook in these careers is on the rise in many countries and/or regions where there is an increase in population.
=== Education === In the United States' education sector there is a strong demand for teachers in numerous regions across the country. There are currently fifty-one "hot spots" with a demand for educators in these regions. Amongst these fifty-one hot spots, five of the regions are with an incredible need for educators in both the primary and secondary education sector. The areas of desperate need include: Las Vegas, Nevada; the Northern region of Oklahoma; Kansas City, Missouri; the Central region of Arkansas; and the Western region of Mississippi.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Snodgrass|first1=Maria|title=Where We Work|url=https://www.teachforamerica.org/where-we-work|website=Teach For America|accessdate=2015}}</ref>
=== Police === The demand for police officers is another occupation that will experience growth over the next ten years. Because urbanized and metropolitan regions are amongst the fastest growing in the United States, that is generally where the demand for these individuals will be.<ref name="U.S. Department of Labor">{{cite web|title=Occupational Outlook Handbook: Police and Detectives|url=http://www.bls.gov/ooh/protective-service/police-and-detectives.htm#tab-6|website=Bureau of Labor Statistics|accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref>
=== Firefighters === Firefighters are another case in protective services where an increase in demand is expected over the next decade. A seven percent increase in career outlook is to be expected by the year 2022.<ref>{{cite web|title=Occupational Outlook Handbook: Firefighters|url=http://www.bls.gov/ooh/protective-service/firefighters.htm#tab-6|website=Bureau of Labor and Statistics|accessdate=8 Jan 2014}}</ref>
=== Social workers === The demand for [[social worker]]s has an average growth rate in the United States. With a general population increase social workers are needed in all areas of the career field. The demand for social workers is extremely high.<ref>{{cite news|title=Child and Family Social Worker|url=http://money.usnews.com/careers/best-jobs/child-and-family-social-worker|accessdate=2015|agency=U.S. News & World Report L.P}}</ref> The national average for growth in all careers stands at eleven percent, while a projected nineteen percent increase in social work is needed to fulfill the sectors responsibility to the general public.<ref>{{cite web|title=Occupational Outlook Handbook: Social Workers|url=http://www.bls.gov/ooh/community-and-social-service/social-workers.htm#tab-6|website=Bureau of Labor Statistics|accessdate=8 Jan 2014}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Street-level bureaucrat !! Number of employees—2012 !! Projected work force—2022 !! Percentage growth |- | Police || 780,000 || 821,000 || 5% |- | Firefighters || 307,000 || 372,300 || 7% |- | Teachers || 1,361,200 || 1,529,100 || 12% |- | Social workers || 607,000 || 721,500 || 19% |}
== Problems ==
=== Corruption and accountability === Corruption in street-level bureaucracy is a violation of the ethical codes of conduct, laws and regulations that have been established by the government and its agencies. An example of corruption would be cases where a [[police officer]] or [[border guard]] accepted a [[bribe]] from a member of the public in return for not enforcing a law or regulation. There are many agencies which define and interpret what is acceptable ethical behavior and what is not.<ref>[http://www.oge.gov/uploadedfiles/education/education_resources_for_ethics_officials/resources/code_of_ethics_poster.pdf]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = http://www.oge.gov/uploadedfiles/education/education_resources_for_ethics_officials/resources/code_of_ethics_poster.pdf|url = http://www.oge.gov/uploadedfiles/education/education_resources_for_ethics_officials/resources/code_of_ethics_poster.pdf|website = www.oge.gov|accessdate = 2015-05-06}}</ref> Violation of these rules or ethical codes of conduct by street-level bureaucrats has repercussions that effect not only the person or agency involved, but also the general public that these street-level bureaucracies serve. Neutrality and impartiality in following policies and procedures is what is expected and most remain separate from person feelings or views. Here is a link to a social work case that let personal feelings override there ethical responsibility.<ref>[http://www.socialworktoday.com/archive/EoENovDec08.shtml]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Deception in Social Work|url = http://www.socialworktoday.com/archive/EoENovDec08.shtml|website = www.socialworktoday.com|accessdate = 2015-05-06|first = Great|last = Inc.}}</ref>
Another example for corruption in street-level bureaucracy are black market payments for doctors and nurses, as part of the shadow economy. The term "black market medicine" refers to a variety of illegal actions that individuals take in order to obtain healthcare services for themselves. Such actions include direct payments to doctors in government hospitals to improve one's position on the waiting list (especially for surgeries) or payments to doctors so they will treat the patient personally. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cohen|first=Nissim|date=2016|title=How Culture Affects Street-Level Bureaucrats’ Bending the Rules in the Context of Informal Payments for Health Care: The Israeli Case|url=https://doi.org/10.1177/0275074016665919|journal=The American Review of Public Administration|volume=48|pages=175-187|via=Sage}}</ref>
[[Accountability]] is the means by which these codes are upheld and to ensure moral and ethical practices within these bureaucratic agencies. There is much debate over the methodology of how exactly these agencies should be held accountable. Accountability is divided into five categories: transparency, liability, controllability, responsibility, and responsiveness.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Pathologies of Accountability: ICANN and the Challenge of "Multiple Accountabilities Disorder" - Koppell - 2005 - Public Administration Review - Wiley Online Library|url = http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/j.1540-6210.2005.00434.x|journal = Public Administration Review|access-date = 2015-05-06|doi=10.1111/j.1540-6210.2005.00434.x|volume=65|pages=94–108}}</ref>
Two major accountability processes are compliance based and performance based. "Traditionally, accountability has involved defining rules and procedures and then employing various means to ensure compliance with these expectations"<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|url = |title = THE ACCOUNTABILITY PARADOX IN AN AGE OF REINVENTION: The perennial problem of preserving character and judgment|last = Jos|first = P.H.|date = 2004|journal = Administration & Society|doi = 10.1177/0095399704263479|pmid = |last2 = Tompkins|first2 = M.E.|issue = 3|volume = 36|pages = 255–281}}</ref> Performance-based practices rely on standardized processes that measure performance in terms of output and results.<ref name=":6" /> Yet compliance based, and performance based accountability has limitations for measuring the efficiency, effectiveness, equity, and economy of the bureaucracy. Furthermore, accountability stems from a multidimensional perspective, which includes the general public the bureaucracy serves, peers and co-workers, office managers, public administrators, and elected officials.
=== Discretion ===
[[Discretion]] can be defined as a component in the decision making process that determines an individual's action or non-action.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Is There A Need for Control?|last = Carrington|first = Keith|date = 2005|journal = Public Administration Quarterly|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |volume = 29|pages = 140–161|issue = 1}}</ref> Carrington divides discretion into two major components as the freedom the decision maker has to choose between different actions; and the decision to act or not act through the rules and judgment of the decision maker.<ref name=":0" /> Michael Lipsky states street level bureaucrats have discretion because human judgment is in the nature of service work that machines could not replace.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = Street-Level Bureaucracy|last = Lipsky|first = Michael|publisher = Russell Sage Foundation|year = 2010|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> Street level bureaucrats are responsible for making appropriate decisions that are appropriate for clients and their situations. Lipsky states all street level bureaucrats will confront situations in which they need to depart from service ideals in order to cope with both expectations from their jobs and the public ideals.
According to Lipsky, the exercise of discretion among street level bureaucrats is critical in how public servants interact with citizens on a daily basis. He claims to understand these acts of discretion once must analyze the outcome of agency performance the public experiences as a combined result of agency rules and street level bureaucrats responses to unsanctioned work.<ref name=":1" /> Lipsky said the use of discretion by street level bureaucrats can’t be removed from everyday practice due to the complexity and uncertainty of human service work. Carrington identifies the fear of power abuse as a major reason for the opposition of discretion in the arena of street level bureaucrats and its citizens. In order to control problems in discretionary action there has been a demand for control by understanding the social situations in which discretion varies.<ref name=":0" /> Marissa Kelly also examines the use of discretion among street level bureaucrats to assert that discretion can either enhance or inhibit street level bureaucrats’ implementation of justice. She asserts that whether discretion is appropriate or not justice theories need to be further examined.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Theories of Justice and Street-Level Discretion|last = Kelly|first = Marisa|date = 1994|journal = Journal of Public Administration Research and Theory: J-PART|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |volume = 4|issue = 2|pages = 119–140}}</ref>
=== Lack of resources ===
Lipsky concludes that the lack of resources causes street level bureaucrat to develop simplified routines for processing cases that influence their everyday tasks. These routines for decisionmaking affect public policy.<ref name=":1" /> He states that street level bureaucrats are taught implementation skills instead of learning about how to find more resources, knowledge and information that would help them to implement policies more effectively.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Understanding Implementation: Street-Level Bureaucrats' Resources for Reform|last = Hill|first = Heather|date = 2003|journal = Journal of Public Administration|doi = 10.1093/jpart/mug024|pmid = |access-date = |volume = 13|issue = 3|pages = 265–282}}</ref> Hill identifies several implementation resources street level bureaucrats often lack such as; research resources, appropriate resources on how to shape specific policies for their specific situation, and access to expertise and skills training to better their decision-making and awareness in specific challenging situations that arise at the street level.<ref name=":5" /> Another key resource that front-line bureaucrats often lack is time to fully assess individual cases. In social services, social workers often have such a large caseload that they can only see social assistance recipients or applicants for a very short time each week. As a result, social workers have to make very rapid decisions as to whether to approve or deny welfare benefits.
== Role of technology== [[File:RIAN archive 440889 Mamonovo-Avtodorozhnoye border-control checkpoint on the Russian-Polish border in the Kaliningrad Region.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A border guard checks a computer display when a citizen comes to the service window.]] Technological advances such as the widespread availability of the Internet and online databases have had a major impact on street-level bureaucracy and the front-line civil servants who provide services to citizens. There are two major theories on how technology has impacted this sector: curtailment theory and enablement theory. Curtailment theory holds that increasing technological advances hinder street-level bureaucrats and their ability to perform effectively; especially concerning their ability to exercise discretion on complex cases. Enablement theory holds that increasing technological advances, at best, empower the existing abilities of the street-level bureaucrat and better inform the citizen. At worst, the effects of technology are ambiguous.
=== Curtailment theory ===
It was first argued by Snellen that increasing technological advances (ITA) "deeply challeng[e] [the street-level bureaucrat's] ability to manipulate information."<ref name=":1"/><ref name=":2">{{cite journal|last1 = Snellen|first1 = I|title = Electronic Governance: Implications for Citizens, Politicians and Public Servants|journal = International Review of Administrative Sciences|date = 2002|volume = 68|issue = 2|pages = 183–198|doi=10.1177/0020852302682002}}</ref> Snellen believed it was the ability to manipulate information that gave the SLB's their power. He further argued that as more decisions are made by computers or software, SLB's will lose their discretionary powers and they will shift to other actors.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{cite journal|last1 = Buffat|first1 = Aurelien|title = Street-Level Bureaucracy and E-Government|journal = Public Management Review|date = 2013|volume = 17|issue = 1|pages = 149–161|doi=10.1080/14719037.2013.771699}}</ref> For example, in the 2010, some government organizations use online application forms for programs in which the computer program, rather than a human front-line bureaucrat, will reject applications which are incomplete. In a pre-technological advances era, a front-line bureaucrat might have used his or her discretion over decisions to allow an application in which some of the information requests are not completed (e.g., due to urgent need on the part of the citizen or the existence of an emergency situation). For example, in the 1960s and 1970s, if a social worker received a hand-written, pen-and-paper application from a [[homeless]] person for [[social assistance]], the bureaucrat might approve the application even if the applicant did not have a street address or the required identification documents, to ensure that the applicant remained housed and safe.
However, there are four problems with this thesis. First, it is implied, but never proven, that with the arrival of more technology, discretion at the frontline will diminish or become non-existent.<ref name=":3" /> Second, Snellen's definition of the SLB's source of power is too narrow and does not take into account other sources of discretion.<ref name=":3" /> Third, this thesis only pertains to particular public organizations and does not apply to more common types of street-level bureaucracies such as police departments, schools, or social welfare departments.<ref name=":3" /> Lastly, this theory does not take into account how SLB's and other caseworkers actually utilize this new technology and how that might affect their performance.
=== Enablement theory ===
In contrast to the curtailment theory, a 2007 study by Jorna and Wagenaar showed that ITA was able to increase the amount of work done while cutting down on inconsistencies.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Iron Cage Strengthened? Discretion and Digital Discipline|last = Jorna|first = F|date = 2007|journal = Public Administration|doi = 10.1111/j.1467-9299.2007.00640.x|pmid = |access-date = |last2 = Wagenaar|first2 = P|volume = 85|issue = 1|pp = 189–214}}</ref> However, the meaning and content of this work was not able to be captured and understood by ITA. A 2004 study by Vitalis and Duhaut highlighted the ambiguous nature of ITA.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = Nouvelles Technologies De L'information Et De La Communication Et Relation Administrative: De La Relation De Guichet A La Relation De Reseau|last = Vitalis|first = A|date = 2004|journal = Revue Francaise D'Administration Publique|doi = |pmid = |last2 = Duhaut|first2 = N|volume = 110|issue = 1}}</ref> It was shown that the [[Internet]] or other forms of technology were utilized for simpler tasks, and more elaborate and complex matters were dealt with face-to-face with citizens. Vitalis and Duhaut come to the conclusion that a SLB has their discretionary power enhanced by ITA, and citizens benefit from ITA by being better informed of their rights when dealing with SLBs and their institutions.<ref name=":4" /> This theory maintains that discretion by the SLB is not hindered in anyway by ITA and will continue to do their jobs effectively. This theory also focuses more on how ITA is utilized by both citizens and state agents which puts more emphasis on the ability of ITA to further help and empower SLBs and citizens.<ref name=":3" />

{{Infobox person | name = Tomy Winata | image = Tomy_Winata.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Guo Shuo Feng 郭說鋒 | birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1958|07|23}} | birth_place = [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[Indonesia]]n | known_for = Owner and Chairman of Artha Graha Group Founder of Artha Graha Care Foundation ([[Artha Graha Peduli Foundation]]) | occupation = Entrepreneur, Philanthropist
}} '''Tomy Winata''' (pronounced {{IPA-id|ˈtomi wiˈnata|}} and sometimes misspelled as Tommy Winata); born '''Guo Shuo Feng 郭說鋒''' on 23 July 1958; is an [[Indonesia]]n businessman with interests in banking, property, gambling and infrastructure, whose wealth comes from his business deals for the [[Indonesian National Armed Forces|Indonesian Military]].<ref name="smh030509">{{cite web |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/dili-tycoon-deal-triggers-alarm-20090502-aqtj.html | title=Dili tycoon deal triggers alarm |last1 = Murdoch |first1= Lindsay | last2 = Hyland | first2 = Tom |publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]| date=3 May 2009 |accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tokohindonesia.com/daftar-tokoh/article/283-direktori/2054-tommy-winata | title=Tommy Winata: Artha Group Boss |author= |date= |work= |publisher=''Tokoh Indonesia'' |accessdate=2 June 2011|language=id}}</ref> His philanthropic interests include the environment,<ref>[http://finance.detik.com/read/2012/12/18/142317/2121446/4/kisah-tomy-winata-harimau-dan-lingkungan-hidup Wawancara Khusus CEO TWNC: Kisah Tomy Winata, Harimau dan Lingkungan Hidup], ''detik.com'', 18 December 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.beritalingkungan.com/2013/01/ketika-tw-mendukung-konservasi-harimau.html Ketika TW Mendukung Konservasi Harimau], ''beritalingkungan.com'', 29 January 2013.</ref> particularly the [[Tambling Wildlife Nature Conservation]] a 45,000 hectare forest, endangered wildlife and sea conservation area, located in southern [[Sumatra]].
He is the son of an automobile spare parts trader and left school in the seventh grade upon which he sold ice pops to support his family. According to [[The Washington Post]], he then "rose from a car washer and office boy to become one of the nation's richest men". In 2006, he was listed as #35 on a [[Forbes]] list of "the 40 richest men in Indonesia".<ref name="forbes">{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/lists/2006/80/06indonesia_Tomy-Winata_RSXG.html |title=Indonesia's 40 Richest: #35 Tomy Winata |author= |date=7 September 2006 |work= |publisher=''Forbes'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref>
==Business career== Winata's business empire has been developed under the Artha Graha Group and Artha Graha Network. In 1988, he worked with the Indonesian Army Foundation to rescue a troubled local bank, Bank Propelat, and subsequently changed its name to Bank Artha Graha.{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} In mid-1997, in cooperation with [[Bank Indonesia]] he bailed out Bank Arta Prima,{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} which was then merged with Bank Artha Graha. In 2003, Artha Graha Group took over Bank Inter-pacific, Tbk (a publicly listed company).{{citation needed|date=June 2013}} In 2005, Bank Inter-pacific, Tbk acquired Bank Artha Graha becoming Bank Artha Graha Internasional, Tbk (INPC.JK).{{citation needed|date=June 2013}}
Winata is involved in the property sector through PT Jakarta International Hotels and Development, Tbk (JIHD.JK, a publicly listed company), which owns Borobudur Hotel in Central Jakarta, and PT Danayasa Arthatama, Tbk (SCBD.JK, a publicly listed company), which owns the Sudirman Central Business District (SCBD) in the heart of Jakarta.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://scbd.com/menu/page/profile | title = Profil | publisher = SCDB Company Profile | access-date = 8 January 2018 | language = Indonesian}}</ref> SCBD includes the Indonesian Stock Exchange Building. Winata plans to build the Signature Tower Building-Jakarta, a 111-storey skyscraper, which will be the fifth tallest building in the world, in the center of the SCBD. He has said the mega-project is part of his mission to show the world that "Indonesia can".<ref>[http://www.antarasumbar.com/berita/nasional/d/0/285152/tomy-winata-indonesia-jadi-pemain-penting-dunia.html Tomy Winata: Indonesia Jadi Pemain Penting Dunia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017020735/http://www.antarasumbar.com/berita/nasional/d/0/285152/tomy-winata-indonesia-jadi-pemain-penting-dunia.html |date=2013-10-17 }}, ''antarasumbar.com'', 23 April 2013.</ref> His vision is to make SCBD the "Manhattan of Indonesia".<ref>[http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/business/jakarta-can-be-a-new-manhattan-tomy-winata/587266 Jakarta Can Be a 'New Manhattan': Tomy Winata'] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130424000904/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/business/jakarta-can-be-a-new-manhattan-tomy-winata/587266 |date=2013-04-24 }}, ''The Jakarta Post'', 22 April 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.jurnas.com/news/90197/Jakarta_Bisa_Jadi_Kota_Yang_Diperhitungkan_Dunia/1/Nasional/Ibu_Kota Jakarta Bisa Jadi Kota Yang Diperhitungkan Dunia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017081107/http://www.jurnas.com/news/90197/Jakarta_Bisa_Jadi_Kota_Yang_Diperhitungkan_Dunia/1/Nasional/Ibu_Kota |date=2013-10-17 }}, ''jurnas.com'', 22 April 2013.</ref>
He is active in the infrastructure sector, through the company PT Bangungraha Sejahtera Mulia, which obtained support from the governors of [[Banten]] and [[Lampung]] provinces to be the lead investor for the [[Sunda Strait Bridge]]<ref>[http://ekbis.rmol.co/read/2013/04/23/107555/Pengusaha-Nasional-Dukung-Pembangunan-Jembatan-Selat-Sunda- Pengusaha Nasional Dukung Pembangunan Jembatan Selat Sunda], ''Rakyat Merdeka Online'', 23 April 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.suarapembaruan.com/ekonomidanbisnis/tomy-winata-indonesia-bisa-buat-sejarah/34208 Wawancara CNBC 'Tomy Winata: Indonesia Bisa Buat Sejarah'], ''Suara Pembaruan Online'', 20 April 2013.</ref> project which, if it proceeds, will be the largest single infrastructure project ever undertaken in Indonesia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bisniskeuangan.kompas.com/read/2009/08/31/1953406/tomy.winata.didukung.gubernur.banten.dan.lampung |title=Tomy Winata Didukung Gubernur Banten dan Lampung |author= |date=31 August 2009 |work= |publisher=''Kompas'' |accessdate=2 June 2011|language=id}}</ref> Based on Indonesian Presidential Regulation Number 86, dated 2 December 2011, the Lampung-Banten consortium with PT Bangungraha Sejahtera Mulia was appointed to be the Project Initiator to work on a feasibility study for the Sunda Strait Bridge Project and Strategic Area Development.<ref>[http://www.rmol.co/read/2013/04/23/107567/Tomy-Winata:-Ground-Breaking-JSS-Sangat-Sulit-Dilakukan-Tahun-2014 Tomy Winata: Ground Breaking JSS Sangat Sulit Dilakukan Tahun 2014], ''Rakyat Merdeka Online'', 23 April 2013.</ref> Following the Presidential Regulation, Banten and Lampung provinces together with PT Bangun Sejahtera Mulia established a joint venture company called PT Graha Banten Lampung Sejahtera (GBLS) to conduct the Sunda Strait feasibility study. Based on its pre-feasibility study, Sunda Strait Project construction cost was estimated around US$10 billion and will take around 8 to 10 years to develop.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tempointeractive.com/hg/nasional/2010/11/02/brk,20101102-288905,uk.html |title=Consortium Teams Up with China to Build Sunda Strait Bridge |author= |date=2 November 2010 |work= |publisher=''Tempo'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref>
The Sunda Strait Bridge Project <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/07/05/us-bank-eyes-sunda-strait-bridge-project.html |title=US bank eyes Sunda Strait Bridge project |author= The Jakarta Post|date=5 July 2012 |work= |publisher=''The Jakarta Post'' |accessdate=}}</ref> has progressed from an "impossible dream" in 2002 to becoming "almost a possible reality" in 2012, but in 2014 new president [[Joko Widodo]] shelved the project.<ref name=Shelve2014>{{cite news|first=Satria|last=Sambijantoro|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2014/11/03/no-more-sunda-strait-bridge-plan.html|title=No more Sunda Strait Bridge plan|work=The Jakarta Post|date=3 November 2014|accessdate=5 July 2017}} See also {{cite news|url=http://www.globalindonesianvoices.com/17165/new-government-will-not-prioritize-sunda-strait-bridge-project/|title=New Government Will Not Prioritize Sunda Strait Bridge Project|work=Global Indonesian Voices|date=2 November 2014|accessdate=5 July 2017}}</ref>
Winata also has business ventures outside of Indonesia, including in [[Timor Leste]], where he was given approval in secret to build a hotel and shopping complex on government-owned land without having to submit his bid to a tendering process.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/specialfeatures/the-land-that-indonesia-lost/437236 |title=The land that Indonesia lost |author=Joe Cochrane |date=25 April 2011 |work= |publisher=''The Jakarta Globe'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref><ref name="smh030509"/>
Besides his legal operations, Tomy is also a member of the so-called "nine dragons", a group comprising the major individuals behind Jakarta's gambling industry, despite the practice being banned in Indonesia.<ref name = "icw">{{Citation | author = Danang Widoyoko | author2 = Irfan Muktiono | author3 = Adnan Topan Husodo | author4 = Barly Harliem Noe | author5 = Agung Wijaya | title = Bisnis Militer Mencari Legitimasi (The Military's Business Seeks Legitimacy | language = Indonesian | publisher = [[Indonesia Corruption Watch]] | url = https://bukuicw.files.wordpress.com/2008/07/bisnis-militer-mencari-legitimasi_ind.pdf |accessdate=16 June 2016}}</ref>
Aside from his businesses, Winata has established a social non-profit foundation called [[Artha Graha Peduli Foundation]] (AG Peduli Foundation),<ref>[http://www.beritasatu.com/makro/109141-tomy-winata-bukan-kerajaan-bisnis-tapi-membangun-masyarakat-dan-lingkungan.html Tomy Winata: Bukan Kerajaan Bisnis Tapi Membangun Masyarakat dan Lingkungan], ''BeritaSatu.com'', 20 April 2013.</ref> which has five major social activities: provision of emergency relief to victims of natural disasters in Indonesia and abroad; humanitarian programs in food resilience, education and health; programs to save the environment; people empowerment through Small and Medium Enterprises (SMEs); and provision of legal assistance for the underprivileged.
==Environmentalism== Winata runs a rescue center for the critically endangered [[Sumatran tiger]] in<ref name="The New York Times">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/22/world/asia/22tigers.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&|title=Trying to Save Wild Tigers by Rehabilitating Them |author= |date=21 April 2010 |work= |publisher=''The New York Times''}}</ref> Tambling Wildlife Nature Conservation, a park in [[Lampung Province]], Sumatra. Here he tries to reintroduce "[[conflict tigers]]"—tigers that have attacked or killed humans—into the wild.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/news/Indonesian-tycoon-Tomy-Winata-bids.6251813.jp |title=Indonesian tycoon Tomy Winata bids to save Sumatran tigers by release back into the wild |author=Norimitsu Onishi |date=25 April 2010 |work= |publisher=''Scotland on Sunday'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref> TWNC has released five Sumatran tigers back to the TWNC forest,<ref name="The Jakarta Post">{{cite web |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2009/06/05/three-more-tigers-be-released-tambling-forest.html |title=Three more tigers to be released in Tambling forest |author= Oyos Saroso H.N.|date=5 June 2009 |work= |publisher=''The Jakarta Post''}}</ref> and was also able to release other protected wildlife and animals such as crocodiles and turtles. In addition to 45,000 hectares of forest, TWNC includes 14,500 hectares of sea conservation area.<ref>[http://www.kapanlagi.com/showbiz/hollywood/kylie-minogue-ketakutan-di-depan-gerbang-harimau.html Kylie Minogue Ketakutan di Depan Gerbang Harimau'], ''KapanLagi.com'', 5 July 2011.</ref>
Winata has cooperated with the [[National Anti-Narcotics Agency (Indonesia)|Indonesian Narcotics Agency]] (Badan Narkotika Nasional-BNN) to organize a [[drug rehabilitation]] <ref name="UNODC">{{cite web |url=http://www.unodc.org/southeastasiaandpacific/en/2012/12/ed-tambling-rehab/story.html|title=For an ecology of the mind: blending drug rehab with nature conservation in Sumatra |author= UNODC |date=8 December 2012 |work= |publisher=''UNODC''}}</ref> program in TWNC.<ref>[http://www.bisnis.com/photos/detail/10/bnn-gandeng-tomy-winata BNN Gandeng Tomy Winata] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130616020027/http://www.bisnis.com/photos/detail/10/bnn-gandeng-tomy-winata |date=2013-06-16 }}, ''Bisnis.com'', 17 February 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.bisnisindonesia.info/rehabilitasi-pecandu-narkoba-bnn-gandeng-tomy-winata Rehabilitasi Pecandu Narkoba: BNN Gandeng Tomy Winata]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, ''Bisnis Indonesia'', 17 February 2013.</ref> The program combines rehab and environmental conservation, encouraging former drug users to re-establish their lives and livelihoods through work in TWNC conservation and eco-tourism. This program was presented by Winata at the [[UNODC]] (United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime) 2013 Annual Meeting in Vienna, Austria.<ref>[http://www.investor.co.id/home/tomy-winata-paparkan-twnc-di-wina/56899 Tomy Winata Paparkan TWNC di Wina], ''Investor Daily'', 18 March 2013.</ref> UNODC's Executive Director, [[Yuri Fedotov]], expressed appreciation to Winata for the TWNC program, and said UNODC will encourage other countries to visit Tambling to study its drug rehabilitation program.
[[File:CR7_and_Tomy_WInata.jpg|thumb|left|Cristiano Ronaldo becomes ambassador for Mangrove Care Forum Bali]] In March 2013, in Madrid, Spain, Winata together with the Bali Mangrove Care Forum appointed "[[Cristiano Ronaldo]]" (CR7), the top Real Madrid soccer player, to be the Ambassador of Mangroves.<ref>[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/03/17/ronaldo-ambassador-mangrove.html-0 Ronaldo ambassador for mangrove], ''The Jakarta Post'', 17 March 2013.</ref><ref>[http://sport.detik.com/sepakbola/read/2013/03/11/190212/2191834/424/cristiano-ronaldo-jadi-duta-pelestarian-mangrove-di-Indonesia Cristiano Ronaldo Jadi Duta Pelestarian Mangrove di Indonesia], ''detik.com'', 11 March 2013.</ref> Winata and Ronaldo agreed to conserve existing mangroves and plant new ones, especially in Bali surrounding areas.<ref>[http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/news/cr7-to-help-protect-bali-mangroves/ CR7 to Help Protect Bali Mangrove], ''Jakarta Globe'', 13 March 2013.</ref>
==The Press== In a high-profile case against the news magazine ''[[Tempo magazine (Indonesia)|Tempo]]'' following an article's "Ada Tomy in Tenebang?" (Is there Tomy in [[Tanah Abang]] ?) published in the March 3, 2003 issue of ''[[Tempo magazine (Indonesia)|Tempo]]'',<ref name="WP">{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A42646-2004Aug28.html |title=Magazine Case Tests Indonesian Press Freedom |author=Ellen Nakashima |date=29 April 2004 |work= |publisher=''The Washington Post'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref> ''Tempo'' editor-in-chief [[Bambang Harymurti]] was found guilty.<ref name="smh030509"/>
The Central Jakarta District Court ordered ''[[Tempo magazine (Indonesia)|Tempo]]'' magazine to publicly apologize and to pay a fine of 500 million rupiah (US$59,000). Tomy filed libel charges against PT Tempo Inti Media; chief editor Bambang Harymurti; chief deputy editor Toriq Hadad; reporters Ahmad Taufik, Bernarda Rurit, and Cahyo Junaidi; publisher Fikri Jufri and corporate director Zulkifli Lubis, according to a Tempo report.<ref>{{cite web|title=Magazine found guilty of libel|url=https://cpj.org/x/ec6|website=cpj.org|accessdate=March 18, 2004}}</ref> The presiding judge stated that, "Tempo failed to find the truth by covering both sides before publishing the article," said a report in [[The Jakarta Post]]. However, this conviction was later overturned on appeal.<ref name="smh030509"/>
In another high-profile case, in the provision of travellers cheques used in 2004 to bribe Indonesian politicians to elect Miranda Swaray Goeltom as Senior Deputy Governor in the Indonesian central bank, [[Bank Indonesia]], has been widely reported in the Indonesian media.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asiasentinel.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3189&Itemid=367 |title=Indonesia's Judicial Flying Circus |author= |date=12 May 2011 |work= |publisher=''Asia Sentinel'' |accessdate=2 June 2011}}</ref> Miranda said he did not know the owner of Bank Artha Graha. "Who owns it?" she told Tempo last Friday. "I do not know."<ref>{{cite web|title=Dekat dengan Bos Artha Graha? Ini Kata Miranda|url=https://nasional.tempo.co/read/news/2012/01/30/063380463/dekat-dengan-bos-artha-graha-ini-kata-miranda|website=nasional.tempo.co|publisher=Tempo.co|accessdate=30 January 2012}}</ref>

{{use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Valentine Nekesa | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1997|09|06}} | birth_place = [[Kenya]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = | occupation = Entrepreneur, Motivational Speaker, Designer and Model | years_active = | nationality = Kenyan | ethnicity = | citizenship = Kenyan | residence = [[Nairobi]] | known_for = Safaricom's BYOB's first winner | networth = | home_town = | title = Founder and CEO of ''Nekesa Queens Limited'' | website = | spouse = | |}} '''Valentine Nekesa''', is an [[entrepreneur]], [[designer]] and [[motivational speaker]], who is the Founder of '''Nekesa Queens Limited''', a company that she formed in 2014, at age 17.<ref name="One">{{cite web| author=Business Daily Africa | url=http://host.nationmedia.com/Top40Under40-2017.pdf |format=PDF |title=Top 40 Women Under 40 in Kenya 2017 | date=26 October 2017 | accessdate=25 November 2017 | publisher=[[Nation Media Group]] | location=Nairobi}}</ref><ref name="Two">{{cite web| url=https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/business/article/2001235178/the-high-school-hobby-that-bagged-nekesa-sh5-million | title=The high school hobby that bagged Nekesa Sh5 million | first=Mumbi |last=Kinyua |location=Nairobi |newspaper=[[The Standard (Kenya)]] |accessdate=25 November 2017 |date=5 April 2017}}</ref>
==Background and education== She was born and raised in [[Webuye]],<ref name="Three">{{cite web| url=http://www.nation.co.ke/lifestyle/How-I-stitched-together-my-life-after-losing-mum/1190-4126092-138qb3c/index.html |title=My Hustle: How I stitched together my life after losing mum | newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] |first=Thomas |location=Nairobi |date=5 October 2017 |accessdate=25 November 2017 |last=Rajula}}</ref> in [[Bungoma County]], in western [[Kenya]]. The relationship between her father, ''Boniface Simiyu'', a.k.a. ''Yankee'' and Valentine has not always been strong. Nekesa was raised by her mother. In 2009, Valentine's mother passed away when Valentine was only 12 years old.<ref name="Three"/>
With the support of her uncle, [[Francis Atwoli]] and his wife ''Roselinda Atwoli'', she attended "Kakamega Primary and Moi Girls’ High School", in [[Eldoret]]. In 2015, she was admitted to [[Mount Kenya University]], where she is pursuing a [[Bachelor of Information Technology]] (BIT) degree.<ref name="One"/><ref name="Two"/><ref name="Three"/>
==Career== In 2008, at age 11 years when she was a student in Senior One, a friend asked her to make her an outfit so that she could participate in the school pageant. The friend was satisfied and that encouraged the budding designer to design more outfits. While in high school, she continued to design outfits for different people.<ref name="Two"/>
In 2014, after high school. while waiting to enter university, a friend asked her to make her an outfit for an event. Valentine invested Sh1,000 (approx. US$10) and earned Sh1,500 (approx. US$15). Thus her company ''VN Designs'' was created. A cousin, donated a sewing machine so Valentine could make her outfits in-house.<ref name="Two"/>
In February 2017, at age 19 years, she entered a television [[reality show]], sponsored by [[Safaricom]]. The eight-week show attracted 12 contestants and in the end Valentine Nekesa won. The prize was a cash prize of Sh3 million (approx. US$30,000) and Sh2 million (approx. 20,000) in services from participating Kenyan businesses. She intends to use her winnings to expand her business, which had three employees as of October 2017.<ref name="One"/><ref name="Two"/><ref name="Three"/><ref>{{cite web| url=http://sokodirectory.com/2017/03/19-year-valentine-nekesa-winner-of-blaze-byob-tv-show-grand-finale/ |title=19-year Valentine Nekesa Announced Winner of BLAZE BYOB TV Show at Grand Finale | accessdate=25 November 2017 | date=28 March 2017 |publisher=Sokodirectory.com |author=Soko Directory Team |location=Nairobi}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| accessdate=25 November 2017 | url=http://nairobinews.nation.co.ke/news/nekesa-no-life-winning-sh5m-blaze-byob-video/ |title=Nekesa: I Have No Life After Winning Sh5 Million In Blaze BYOB - Includes Video | date=2 April 2017 |publisher=Nairobi News a division of [[Nation Media Group]] | location=Nairobi | first=Hilary |last=Kimuyu}}</ref>
==Other considerations== In October 2017, Valentine Nekesa was named among "The Top 40 Women Under 40 in Kenya 2017", by [[Business Daily Africa]], a daily English language business daily newspaper published by the [[Nation Media Group]].<ref name="One"/>

{{Infobox person | name = Vincenzo Florio Jr. | image = Le chevalier Vincenzo Florio en 1905.jpg | alt = | caption = Vincenzo Florio Jr. in 1905 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1883|3|18}} | birth_place = [[Palermo]], [[Kingdom of Italy]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1959|1|6|1883|3|18}} | death_place = [[Épernay]], [[France]] | nationality = Italian | other_names = | occupation = Entrepreneur and racecar driver | known_for = Member of the [[Florio]] family and founder of the [[Targa Florio]] }}
'''Vincenzo Florio Jr.''' (18 March 1883 – 6 January 1959) was an Italian entrepreneur, heir of the rich [[Florio]] economic dynasty, one of the wealthiest Italian families during the late 19th century.<ref name=florio>{{it icon}} [http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/florio/ Flòrio], Treccani Enciclopedie on line (retrieved 10 April 2018)</ref> An automobile enthusiast, he is best known as the founder of the [[Targa Florio]].
==Early life== He was the son of the [[Senate of the Kingdom of Italy|Senator of the Kingdom of Italy]], [[Ignazio Florio Sr.]] and baroness Giovanna D'Ondes Trigona. He was born in [[Palermo]] and was named after his grandfather [[Vincenzo Florio Sr.]] (1799–1886) who founded the [[Florio]] wine and spice company. He was the younger brother of [[Ignazio Florio Jr.]]. Not inclined to business, he loved traveling and was a frequent visitor of [[Paris]], [[Nice]], [[Montecarlo]] and [[Cannes]]. Luxury boats were one of his passions: in the family they owned five yachts.<ref name=treccani>{{it icon}} [http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/vincenzo-florio_res-3f57584f-87ed-11dc-8e9d-0016357eee51_%28Dizionario-Biografico%29/ Florio, Vincenzo], by Simone Candela - Treccani Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani - Volume 48 (1997)</ref> In 1909 he married principessa Annina Alliata di Montereale. After her death to [[cholera]] in 1911, he married [[Lucie Henry]] of [[Épernay]], France, a year later.
==Career== [[File:Buste of Vincenzo Florio.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Buste of Vincenzo Florio, located between the spectators balconies at the Targa Florio pitcomplex]] An automobile enthusiast, he initiated the financial basis and the engineering plans for the "Brescia Motor Week" in [[Brescia]], [[Lombardy]]. He had finished third in the 1904 edition, and generously funding the 1905 race, which was renamed [[Coppa Florio]]. He donated 50,000 lire and a Cup for the winner. His greatest fame came from creating the [[Targa Florio]] race in [[1906 Targa Florio|1906]], based on discussions with [[James Gordon Bennett Jr.]] and [[Henri Desgrange]]. The Targa also claimed to be a worldly event not to be missed. Renowned artists, such as [[Alexandre Charpentier]] and [[Leonardo Bistolfi]], were commissioned to design medals. A magazine was initiated, ''Rapiditas'', which aimed to enhance, with graphic and photographic reproductions of the race, the myth of the car and the typical character of modern life, speed.<ref name=treccani/>
Florio also raced himself. His best result was the win in the [[Targa Rignano]] ([[Padova]] - [[Bovolenta]]) 1903, named after Count Rignano, thus inspiring Florio to pick the surname-based Targa Florio. His own racing team, however, got [[Felice Nazzaro]] to leave [[Fiat]] and join as driver,<ref name=treccani/> who had won the 1907 race. In 1913 Vincenzo Florio founded the Automobile Club of Sicily, of which he remained president for a long time.<ref name=treccani/>
==Death== He died at Épernay. He is buried in the family chapel, in the cemetery of [[Santa Maria di Gesù]].
==Commemoration== Florio was also a painter.<ref>{{it icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20070930043815/http://www.comune.palermo.it/Eventi/Palazzo%20Ziino/Secondo_Piano/Florio/florio_e.htm Vincenzo Florio, il gusto della modernità]</ref> The exhibition ''Vincenzo Florio – A taste for modernity'' was on display in [[Palermo]] in 2003.

{{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name =William Kistler Coors | birth_date = {{Birth date|1916|8|11}} | birth_place = [[Golden, Colorado]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2018|10|13|1916|8|11}} | death_place = Golden, Colorado, U.S. | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality =American | other_names = | known_for =Chairman of the [[Coors Brewing Company]] (1959–2000) | education =[[Phillips Exeter Academy]]
[[Princeton University]] | employer = | occupation = | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = |successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse =Geraldine Louise Jackson (m.1941–1962; div.)
Phyllis Mahaffey (m.1963–?;div.)
Rita Bass (m.1995–2015; her death) | partner = | children =three | relations=[[Adolph Coors]] (grandfather); [[Adolph Coors III]], [[Joseph Coors]] (brothers) | parents =[[Adolph Coors II]] (father) | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''William Kistler Coors''' (August 11, 1916 – October 13, 2018) was an American brewery executive with the [[Coors Brewing Company]]. He was affiliated with the company for over 64 years, and was a board member from 1973 to 2003. He was a grandson of [[Adolph Coors]] (1847–1929) the company's founder. ==Biography== Born in [[Golden, Colorado]] on August 11, 1916, he was the son of [[Adolph Coors II]] and Alice Kistler May (1885–1970), and the brother of [[Adolph Coors III]] (1916–60) and Joseph Coors Sr. (1917–2003). Coors earned a bachelor's degree from [[Princeton University]] in 1938, and a master's degree in [[chemical engineering]] in 1939. Coors had three daughters with his first wife Geraldine, who suffered from alcoholism and died of illness.{{what|date=October 2018}}{{cite news|author=Bella Stumbo|title=Brewing Controversy—Coors Clan: Doing It Their Way Series: First of two parts|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|date=September 18, 1988 |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-09-18/news/mn-3400_1_adolph-coors/4 |page=1}} William remarried in the 1960s and he and his wife, Phyllis, had one son, Scott.{{cite news|title=Gay director plays havoc with 'all-US' beer dynasty: Traditional firm encounters problems with its image|publisher=''[[The Observer]]'' |location=London |date=July 21, 2001 |page= 23}} Coors' oldest daughter Geraldine committed suicide August 5, 1983 at the age of 40 after suffering from [[Major depressive disorder|depression]]. Coors [[centenarian|turned 100]] in August 2016{{cite web|url=http://brookstonbeerbulletin.com/historic-beer-birthday-william-k-bill-coors/|title=Historic Beer Birthday: William K. "Bill" Coors|publisher=Brookston Beer Bulletin|author=Jay Brooks|date=August 11, 2016|accessdate=August 13, 2016}} and died on October 13, 2018, aged 102.[https://kdvr.com/2018/10/13/william-bill-coors-former-brewery-leader-dies-at-102 William "Bill" Coors, brewing industry leader, dies at 102]https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/14/obituaries/william-coors-dies-at-102.html ==Career== {{refimprove-section|date=October 2018}} William Coors entered the family business as a chemical engineer for [[Coors Brewing Company]] in 1939. Coors was respected in the industry for his ability in packaging, bottling, and engineering. He is credited with pioneering the recyclable two-piece [[aluminum can]], which is now standard throughout the industry.{{cite news|author=Bartell Nyberg|title=King of Coors: Brewer Climbs to No. 3 With Bill Coors at Helm|publisher=''Denver Post''| date=1990-05-20|page= G1}} In the 1950s, Coors requested $250,000 from his father, CEO [[Adolph Coors, Jr.]], to build an experimental line of aluminum cans. By the early 1960s, can recycling was viable, and the company offered customers a one-cent [[Deposit-refund system|deposit on returned cans]]. Coors was elected to the board of directors in 1973. When the non-brewing assets (e.g., [[CoorsTek|Coors Ceramics Co.]]) of Adolph Coors Co. were spun off in 1992 as ACX Technologies Inc., he served as chairman of both companies. In 2003, at the age of 87, Coors retired from the boards of the Adolph Coors Company and the Coors Brewing Company, although he remained with the company as chief technical adviser.{{cite news|title=William Coors Sets Retirement| publisher=''Denver Post''|date=2003-05-17|page=1}} ==Political views== William Coors' political views were considered to be more moderate and less outspoken than his brother [[Joseph Coors|Joe]]'s. For example, Joe's public opposition to the [[Equal Rights Amendment]] in 1988 earned the company the ire of feminist groups, even though William was on record supporting the amendment. ===Accusations of racism=== Coors was criticized for remarks he made on February 23, 1984, in a seminar held by the Minority Business Development Center in [[Denver]].{{cite news|author=Don Williamson |title=Calls for Coors boycott echo again after speech to blacks brews a storm |publisher=''The San Diego Union''|date=1984-03-12| page=B3}} In off-the-cuff remarks, he stated that "...ancestors were dragged here in chains against their will… I would urge those of you who feel that way to go back to where your ancestors came from, and you will find out that probably the greatest favor that anybody ever did you was to drag your ancestors over here in chains, and I mean it." He also remarked Africa's economic problems stemmed from "a lack of intellectual capacity." Coors apologized in a press conference the next day for his "unfortunate choice of words and lack of sensitivity," and said he hoped his commitment to minority groups spoke louder than his words. He stated that his words were taken out of context by the ''[[Rocky Mountain News]]'', which he later sued for [[Defamation|libel]].{{cite news|author=Kathleen Teltsch| title=Fight Over Coors's Role Upsets Foundation Parley|publisher=''New York Times''|date=1984-04-26|page=A18}} A number of people who attended the speech reported that the remarks were not considered offensive. An informal boycott of Coors was announced by the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People|NAACP]] during a March 2 meeting in Los Angeles. At the time, the [[AFL-CIO]] had been boycotting the company for seven years over a labor dispute.{{cite news|author=Associated Press |title=Coors Beer to Assist Hispanics |publisher=''Boston Globe'' |date=1984-10-30 |page=68}} At least 500 liquor stores in Southern California joined the NAACP boycott, which was suspended five days later when they reached an agreement with the company. In September, the Adolph Coors Company signed an agreement with [[Operation PUSH]] and the NAACP to invest $325 million into black communities over five years, to deposit millions of operating capital in black-owned banks, and to spend $8.8 million on advertising in black-owned media. In October, the company negotiated a similar agreement with [[American GI Forum]] and [[National Council of La Raza|La Raza]] for $300 million. This was the first ever such arrangement between La Raza and any corporation.{{cite news|author=Iver Peterson| title=Making Big Business A Threat It Can't Refuse|publisher=''New York Times''|date=1984-12-02|page=A10}} In 1987, Coors dropped his libel suit after the ''Rocky Mountain News'' printed an article commending Coors' good record with the minority community, and expressing regret for the headline over the February 24, 1984 article.{{cite news|author=Paul Richter |title=Coors' New Brew: Taking Out the Political Aftertaste| publisher=''Los Angeles Times''|date=1987-09-27|page= 1}} ==Positions held== *President – [[Coors Brewing Company]] *Chairman – [[Coors Brewing Company]] *President – [[Castle Rock Foundation]] *Founding Member – The Future 500 *Honorary Chairman – [[SEED (Organisation)|SEED]] *Trustee – [[Colorado School of Mines]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *Baum, Dan. ''Citizen Coors: A Grand Family Saga of Business, Politics, and Beer''. New York: HarperCollins, 2000. {{ISBN|0-688-15448-4}} *[http://www.philipjett.com/books/deathofanheir.php Jett, Philip. ''The Death of an Heir: Adolph Coors III and the Murder That Rocked an American Brewing Dynasty''] New York: St. Martin's Press, 2017. {{ISBN|978-1250111807}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coors, William}} [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:American brewers]] [[Category:American centenarians]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Colorado]] [[Category:Coors family]] [[Category:People from Golden, Colorado]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]]
